[[File:Noticia de la California.jpg|thumb|''Noticia de la California'']] '''Miguel Venegas''' (1680–1764) was a [[Jesuit]] administrator and historian. He is most known for his book ''Noticia de la California'', a standard geographical, historical, and ethnographic description of [[Baja California]], Mexico—a region he never personally visited.
== Biography == Miguel Venegas was born in [[Puebla]], New Spain. He received an academic degree prior to joining the Jesuit order, which he did in 1700 in Tepotzotlán. Five years later he was an ordained member and he taught philosophy and moral theology at the Colegio S. Pedro y S. Pablo de México.<ref name=":0">{{Cite book|title = Diccionario histórico de la Compañia de Jesús: biográfico-temático|last = O'Neill|first = C. E.|publisher = Institutum Historicum|year = 2001|isbn = |location = Rome|pages = 3922|last2 = Domínguez}}</ref> He suffered from health problems and bodily swellings, which obliged him to retire to the Jesuit ranch of Chicomocelo, where he devoted himself to writing and botany until his death in 1764.
As a historian, he was cautious in his investigations, critical in his selection of sources and concerned with discovering the truth.<ref name=":0" /> In his major work on California, he cited [[Georg Marcgrave|Georg Marcgraf]] and [[Willem Piso]]'s ''[[Historia Naturalis Brasiliae]]'' (1648), an important compendium on flora and fauna in Brazil, which circulated widely in northern Europe and beyond.<ref>Neil Safier, "Beyond Brazilian Nature: The Editorial Itineraries of Marcgraf and Piso's ''Historia Naturalis Brasiliae'', in Michiel Van Groesen, ''The Legacy of Dutch Brazil'', New York: Cambridge University Press 2014, p. 171.</ref>
==Published works== [[File:Carte de la Californie 1766.jpg|left|thumb|Map of Baja California, from the 1766 French edition of ''Noticia de la California''.]] In the mid-1730s, he was assigned the task of writing an account of Baja California. This seems to have been, at least in part, to counter the setback to the missionaries' efforts and reputation caused by the [[Pericúes|Pericú]] revolt on the southernmost part of the peninsula in 1734. The historian was given access to the missionaries' correspondence and reports, and he was able to exchange letters with them to acquire further information, which he did through the use of questionnaires.
Venegas' 600-page manuscript, ''Empresas Apostólicas,'' was completed in 1739. It was sent to Spain, but it languished there rather than seeing publication because it was too detailed with regard to military matters.<ref>{{Cite book|title = Jesuit Encounters in the New World: Jesuit Chroniclers, geographers, educators and missionaries in the Americas, 1549-1767|last = Mathes|first = W. M.|publisher = Istituto Storico|year = 1997|isbn = |location = Rome|pages = 62|editor-last = Gagliano|chapter = Jesuit Chroniclers and Chronicles of Northwestern New Spain}}</ref> Another Jesuit historian, [[Andrés Marcos Burriel]], extensively revised Venegas' manuscript in the 1750s, and it was finally published in 1757 as ''Noticia de la California'' in three volumes at Madrid. This work by Venegas and Burriel was subsequently translated into English (1759), Dutch (1761–1762), French (1766–1767), and German (1769–1770), and it became the standard source for information about the early Californias. The original manuscript version was published in a facsimile edition in 1979.
Venegas was a prolific writer, also authoring biographical and theological treatises. Among his other works are a manual on how to administer the sacraments, which remained the official ritual for the Mexican branch of the Catholic church (1731), a biography of [[Juan María de Salvatierra]] (1754a, 1929) and another biography detailing the life of [[Juan Bautista Zappa]] (1754b). Many of these were edited extensively before publication due to Venegas' writing style, which was too lengthy for his fellow Jesuits.<ref>{{Cite book|title = El apóstol Mariano representado en la vida del V.P. Juan María de Salvatierra, de la Compañía de Jesús|last = Venegas|first = Miguel|publisher = Doña María de Rivera|year = 1754|isbn = |location = Mexico City|pages = vi}}</ref>
=== List of books by Venegas === *1731. ''Manual de párrocos, para administrar los santos sacramentos, y exercer otras functiones ecclesiásticas conforme al ritual romano''. J. D. de Hogal, Mexico. *1754a. ''El apóstol Mariano representado en la vida del V.P. Juan María de Salvatierra, de la Compañía de Jesús''. Doña María de Rivera, Mexico City. *1754b. ''Vida y virtudes del V.P. Juan Bautista Zappa de la Compañía de Jesús''. Pablo Nadal, Barcelona. *1757. ''Noticia de la California, y de su conquista temporal, y espiritual hasta el tiempo presente''. Viuda de M. Fernández, Madrid.
Translations of ''Noticia de la California'':
* 1759. ''A Natural and Civil History of California''. James Rivington and James Fletcher, London. * 1761–1762. ''Natuurlyke en burgerlyke historie van California''. Johannes Enschedé, Te Haerlem, Netherlands. * 1766–1767. ''Histoire naturelle et civile de la Californie''. Chez Durand, Paris. * 1769–1770. ''Natürliche und bürgerliche Geschichte von Californien''. Meyerschen Buchhandlung, Lemgo, Germany.
== Further reading == * [[W. Michael Mathes|Mathes, W. Michael]]. 1979. "Supplement: Historical-Biographical Introduction". In ''Obras californianas del padre Miguel Venegas, S.J.'', by Miguel Venegas, vol. 1. Universidad Autónoma de Baja California Sur, La Paz, Mexico. * Venegas, Miguel. 1929. ''Juan María de Salvatierra of the Company of Jesus, Missionary in the Province of New Spain, and Apostolic Conqueror of the Californias''. Arthur H. Clark, Cleveland, Ohio. * Venegas, Miguel. 1979. ''Obras californianas del padre Miguel Venegas, S.J.'' 5 vols. Universidad Autónoma de Baja California Sur, La Paz, Mexico.
==References== {{Reflist}} * {{Authority control}}
{{DEFAULTSORT:Venegas, Miguel}} [[Category:1680 births]] [[Category:1764 deaths]] [[Category:Mexican Jesuits]] [[Category:History of Baja California]] [[Category:Mexican historians]] [[Category:Historians of Baja California]]

{{italic title}} '''''On Weights and Measures''''' is a historical, lexical, [[metrological]], and geographical treatise compiled in 392 [[Common Era|CE]] in [[Salamis, Cyprus|Constantia]] by [[Epiphanius of Salamis]] (c. 315–403). The greater part of the work is devoted to a discussion on ancient Greek and Roman [[Ancient Roman units of measurement|weights and measures]].
The composition was written at the request of a Persian priest, sent to Epiphanius by letter from the Roman emperor in [[Constantinople]].<ref>Allen A. Shaw, ''On Measures and Weights by Epiphanius'', National Mathematics Magazine 11.1 (October 1936: 3–7).</ref><ref>''Epiphanius' Treatise on Weights and Measures - The Syriac Version'' (ed. James Elmer Dean), University of Chicago Press 1935, p. 11 (note 3). The letter was apparently signed jointly by [[Valentinian II]], emperor of the West, and [[Theodosius I|Theodosius]], emperor of the East, as well as Theodosius' two sons, [[Arcadius]] and [[Honorius (emperor)|Honorius]].</ref> Although five fragments of an early Greek version are known to exist, with one entitled περὶ μέτρων καὶ στάθμων (''On Weights & Measures''), added by a later hand,<ref>The Codex Parisinus Graecus 835, as noted by J.E. Dean (ed.), in ''Epiphanius' Treatise on Weights and Measures: The Syriac Version'', (Chicago 1935), Introduction p. 2</ref> this [[Syriac language|Syriac]] version is the only complete copy that has survived. Partial translations in Armenian and Georgian<ref>Found in the “Shatberd codex” MS. 1141, in the library of the ''Obshchestvo rasprostranenifa gramotnosti sredi gruzin'', Tiflis</ref> are also known to exist. Its modern title belies its content, as the work also contains important historical anecdotes about people and places not written about elsewhere.
Two manuscripts of ''On Weights and Measures'', written in Syriac on parchment, are preserved at the [[British Museum]] in [[London]]. The older was found in [[Egypt]] and, according to the colophon, was written in the [[Seleucid era]], in "nine-hundred and sixty-[...]" (with the last digit effaced, meaning, that it was written between the years 649 CE–659 CE). The younger manuscript is designated "Or. Add. 14620".<ref>William Wright, [http://www.trismegistos.org/tm/detail.php?tm=115426 ''Catalogue of Syriac manuscripts in the British Museum''] 2 756 (pp. 717–718)</ref>
The first to attempt a modern publication of Epiphanius' work was [[Paul de Lagarde]] in 1880, who reconstructed the original Syriac text by exchanging it with Hebrew characters,<ref>Paul de Lagarde, ''Veteris Testamenti ab Origene recensiti fragmenta apud Syros servata quinque. Praemittitur Epiphanii de mensuris et ponderibus liber nunc primum integer et ipse syriacus'', Gootingae 1880</ref> and who had earlier published excerpts from several of the Greek fragments treating on weights and measures in his ''Symmicta''.<ref>Paul de Largarde, ''Symmicta'' I, Göttingen 1877, pp. 210–225</ref> In 1973, a critical edition of the Greek text was published by E.D. Moutsoulas in ''Theologia''.<ref>E.D. Moutsoulas, ed., "Epiphanius of Salamis, Concerning Weights and Measures" (Introduction, Commentary, Text and Notes), ''Theologia'', 44 (1973), pp. 157–198</ref>
==Synopsis== ::<small>'''Part One'''</small> In folios [54b–55c], [[Hadrian]]'s journey and arrival in the East is dated "47 years after the destruction of Jerusalem." *Translations In folios [47a–49a]; [51d–52a]; [56d–57b] Epiphanius names four major translations of the [[Hebrew Bible]], made in the Greek tongue: the [[Septuagint|LXX]] made by the seventy-two translators, another by [[Aquila of Pontus]], one by [[Theodotion]], and yet another by [[Symmachus (translator)|Symmachus]]. A fifth Greek translation was discovered in wine jars in [[Jericho]], and a sixth in [[Nicopolis]] near Actium. Afterwards, [[Origen]] arranged six columns of the extant Greek translations and two of the Hebrew side by side, naming it the [[Hexapla]].<ref>''Epiphanius' Treatise on Weights and Measures - The Syriac Version'' (ed. James Elmer Dean), University of Chicago Press 1935, pp. 33–34, 36</ref> Epiphanius expands his description of the translation of the seventy-two translators (known as the Septuagint) and how they were assigned thirty-six cells, two to each cell, on the Pharian island. Two translators translated the [[Book of Genesis]], another two the [[Book of Exodus]], another two the [[Book of Leviticus]], and so forth, until the entire 22 canonical books of the Hebrew Bible had all been translated into the Greek tongue.<ref>Excluding [[Ecclesiastes]] and the [[Song of Solomon]], which books had only later been added to the canon, according to Jewish tradition.</ref> The seventy-two translators were drawn from the twelve tribes of Israel, six men to each tribe who were skilled in the Greek language.
In folios [49a–50a] Epiphanius gives a description of the canonical books of the [[Hebrew Bible]] and translations made of the same. In his day, he notes that the Scroll of Ruth and the Book of Judges were joined together, and considered as one book. So, too, the [[Book of Ezra|Books of Ezra]] and [[Book of Nehemiah|Nehemiah]] were joined, and considered as one book, as were First and Second [[Books of Chronicles|Chronicles]] (''Paraleipomena'') considered as one book, as were the First and Second [[Book of Samuel|Samuel]] (''Book of First and Second Kingdoms'') considered as one book, and the First and Second [[Books of Kings|Kings]] (''Book of Third and Fourth Kingdoms'') considered as one book.<ref>''Epiphanius' Treatise on Weights and Measures - The Syriac Version'' (ed. James Elmer Dean), University of Chicago Press 1935, pp. 18-19</ref>
::<small>'''Part Two'''</small> *Prominent figures In spite of Epiphanius' interest in Jewish themes, his narrative often takes on a distorted and stereotypical view of [[Judaism]], based on the dogmas of his persuasion. Still, he is an invaluable source on the lives of people and places that figure highly in Jewish [[Oral tradition|lore]]. In folios [54a–55c]; [55c–55d] Epiphanius treats on the lives of two prominent persons who became [[proselytes]] to the Jewish religion; the one [[Aquila of Pontus|Aquila]] (known also as Onkelos) who was a relation of [[Hadrian]], and whom he made the overseer of Jerusalem's rebuilding around 115 [[Common Era|CE]].<ref>''Epiphanius' Treatise on Weights and Measures - The Syriac Version'' (ed. James Elmer Dean), University of Chicago Press 1935, p. 30</ref> The other person of interest who is described by him is [[Symmachus (translator)|Symmachus]], also known as ''Sūmkos'' ({{lang-he-n|'''סומכוס'''}}) in rabbinic literature.<ref>See: [[Mishnah]] ''Eruvin'' 3:1; ''Baba Metzia'' 6:5; ''Ḥullin'' 5:3 in ''The Mishnah'' (ed. Herbert Danby), Oxford University Press, 1974; the [[Babylonian Talmud]] ''Eruvin'' 13b, ''Baba Bathra'' 73a, ''Baba Kamma'' 46a, ''et al''.</ref> Symmachus is mentioned as belonging originally to the [[Samaritans|Samaritan]] nation, and is said to have converted to Judaism during the reign of [[Marcus Aurelius|Verus]].<ref>According to Epiphanius, Marcus Aurelius was also called Verus.</ref> He subsequently underwent a second [[circumcision]]<ref>''Epiphanius' Treatise on Weights and Measures - The Syriac Version'' (ed. James Elmer Dean), University of Chicago Press 1935, p. 32</ref> and became a disciple of [[Rabbi Meir]].<ref>[[Babylonian Talmud]] ''Eruvin'' 13b</ref> Symmachus belonged to the fifth generation (165–200 [[Common Era|CE]]) of Rabbinical teachers referred to in the text of the [[Mishnah]].<ref>''The Mishnah'' (ed. [[Herbert Danby]]), Oxford University Press: Oxford 1977, Appendix III, pp. 799–800 {{ISBN|0 19 815402 X}}</ref> The Emperor [[Hadrian]] is said to have passed through [[Palestine (region)|Palestine]] while ''en route'' to Egypt, some 47 years after the destruction of Jerusalem.<ref>''Epiphanius' Treatise on Weights and Measures - The Syriac Version'' (ed. James Elmer Dean), University of Chicago Press 1935, p. 30</ref> ::<small>'''Part Three'''</small> *Weights and Measures Folios [61d–73b] contain a treatise on the known weights and measures used in his day among the [[Jews|Hebrews]], the Greeks and the Romans. He states the equivalent weights for the ''[[Biblical and Talmudic units of measurement#Dry measure|kab]]'' (''cab''),<ref>''Epiphanius' Treatise on Weights and Measures - The Syriac Version'' (ed. James Elmer Dean), University of Chicago Press 1935, p. 68</ref> ''kor'',<ref>A measure of capacity equal to 30 ''modii'' (seahs). v. ''Epiphanius' Treatise on Weights and Measures - The Syriac Version'' (ed. James Elmer Dean), University of Chicago Press 1935, p. 12 (folio 45d). The same is defined in the Talmud (''Baba Bathra'' 86b, 105a) as equal to thirty ''seahs'', a capacity equal to about 395.533 cubic centimeters.</ref> the ''lethekh'' ([[Biblical and Talmudic units of measurement#Dry measure|Lethek]]), [[Homer (unit)|''homer'']], [[Bath (unit)|''bath'']], ''modius'' ([[Hebrew]]: ''seah'' = lit. "measure"),<ref>A measure of capacity equivalent to the volume of 144 medium-sized eggs (9.6 litres); Marcus Jastrow, ''Dictionary of the Targumim, the Talmud Babli and Yerushalmi, and the Midrashic Literature'' (2nd edition), Massachusetts 2006, s.v. '''מודיא''' p. 738.</ref> and ''[[Mina (unit)|mina]]'' ([[Hebrew]]: ''maneh''),<ref>''Epiphanius' Treatise on Weights and Measures - The Syriac Version'' (ed. James Elmer Dean), University of Chicago Press 1935, pp. 60 (§ 51), 65; a weight in silver that was equal to 100 ''[[denarii|denaria]]''.</ref> among others. In folios [62b–62c] Epiphanius distinguishes between "a handful" ({{Lang-he-n|'''מְלֹא כַף'''}}) in [http://www.mechon-mamre.org/p/pt/pt09a17.htm#12 I Kings 17:12] and "a handful" ({{Lang-he-n|'''מְלֹא חֹפֶן'''}}) in [http://www.mechon-mamre.org/p/pt/pt0209.htm#8 Exodus 9:8] and [http://www.mechon-mamre.org/p/pt/pt0316.htm#12 Leviticus 16:12]; in the former case it refers to only one handful, but in latter cases it refers to "a measure of two handfuls."<ref>''Epiphanius' Treatise on Weights and Measures - The Syriac Version'' (ed. James Elmer Dean), University of Chicago Press 1935, p. 47</ref>
::<small>'''Part Four'''</small> *Geography of [[Palestine (region)|Palestine]], [[Asia Minor]] and the [[Levant]] In folios [73b–75a] Epiphanius gives the names of several cities and places of renown, both in his time and in ancient times, such as: [[Mount Ararat]] (§ 61), Aṭaṭ (§ 62), or what is known as the "threshing floor of the thorn bush" ({{Lang-he-n|'''גרן האטד'''}}), and whose description echoes that of [[Rashi]]'s commentary on Genesis 50:10,<ref>Said to be a place about two miles from the Jordan River, called ''Beth-ḥagla'' (lit. "the place of the circuit").</ref> [[Abarim]] (§ 63); [[Eben-Ezer|Aviʿazar]] (§ 68), or what is ''Eḇen haʿezer'' of [[I Samuel]] 4:1, said to be "fourteen [Roman] miles distant east and north of [[Eleutheropolis]], in a valley"; [[Carmel (biblical settlement)|Carmel]]{{nbsp}}(§ 77); [[Mount Carmel|Carmel]] of the sea (§ 78); [[Akko]] (§ 76); [[Anathoth]] (§ 66); [[Azekah]] (§ 64) - a city in whose time was called Ḥ<sup>ǝ</sup>warta;<ref>R. Steven Notley & [[Ze'ev Safrai]], in their book, "Eusebius, ''Onomasticon - The Place Names of Divine Scripture'' (Brill: Leiden 2005, p. 19, note 47), have noted: "According to his (Epiphanius') formulation, it would seem that he was of the opinion that Hiwarta, which means 'white' (''lavan''), is the translation of Azekah. About five kilometers to the southeast of Tell Zechariah is a high hill called Tell el-Beida, meaning in Arabic 'white'. In current maps, the site is named Tell Livnin, which means the hill of bricks (''livanim''), and it is to this that Eusebius (who also wrote about Azekah) most probably referred. 'Azekah' is not 'white', either in Hebrew or in Aramaic. ''Le-azek'' in Hebrew means to remove stones, and then the soil appears a bit paler. It therefore appears that Epiphanius, who was born in Beit Zedek, near [[Eleutheropolis]], identified Azekah with Tell el-Beida. Azekah is six kilometers from Eleutheropolis, and Tell Livnin is eight kilometers from there. Epiphanius adapted the new name to the identification by means of an etymological exegesis that has no linguistic basis. At any rate, no settlement existed on Tell Azekah in the Roman-Byzantine period. The early site moved from the high hill to the fields in the plain at the foot of the tell. It may possibly have moved as fr as Kh. el-Beida, although this is difficult to accept."</ref> [[Bethel]] (§ 73); [[Ophrah (Taybeh)|Ophrah]] (§ 67); [[Carthage]] (§ 79) - where the [[Canaanites]] had migrated from [[Phoenicia]] and who were called in his day ''Bizakanoi'' (scattered people); [[Petra|Rekem]] (§ 71), [[Jaffa]] (§ 75), [[Jerusalem]]{{nbsp}}(§ 74), ''et al.''
==Chronology of the Ptolemies== * [[Ptolemy I Soter|Ptolemy, also called Soter]] (of the Rabbit [''Lagos'']) = reign: 40 years<ref>''Epiphanius' Treatise on Weights and Measures - The Syriac Version'' (ed. James Elmer Dean), University of Chicago Press 1935, pp. 28–29</ref> * [[Ptolemy II Philadelphus|Ptolemy Philadelphus]] = reign: 38 years * [[Ptolemy III Euergetes|Ptolemy the Well-Doer]] (Euergetes) = reign: 24 years * [[Ptolemy IV Philopator|Ptolemy Philopator]] = reign: 21 years * [[Ptolemy V Epiphanes|Ptolemy Epiphanes]] = reign: 22 years * [[Ptolemy VI Philometor|Ptolemy Philometor]] = reign: 34 years * [[Ptolemy VIII Physcon|Ptolemy the Lover of Learning]] and the Well-Doer = reign: 29 years * Ptolemy the Savior (Soter) = reign: 15 years * [[Ptolemy X Alexander I|Ptolemy who is also Alexas]] = reign: 12 years * [[Ptolemy IX Lathyros|Ptolemy, the brother of Alexas]] = reign: 8 years * [[Ptolemy XII Auletes|Ptolemy Dionysius]] = reign: 31 years * [[Cleopatra]], the daughter of Ptolemy = reign: 32 years
==Chronology of the Roman emperors== * [[Augustus]] = reign: 56 years, 6 months<ref>J.E. Dean (ed.), in Epiphanius' ''Treatise on Weights and Measures: The Syriac Version'', (Chicago 1935), pp. 28–29; the chronology of the Caesars resuming on pp. 32, 34–35, and again on pp. 37–39</ref> * [[Tiberius]] = reign: 23 years * [[Caligula|Gaius]] = reign: 3 years, 9 months, 29 days * [[Claudius]] = reign: 13 years, 1 month, 28 days * [[Nero]] = reign: 13 years, 7 months, 27 days * [[Galba]] = reign: 7 months, 26 days * [[Otho]] = reign: 3 months, 5 days * [[Vitellius]] = reign: 8 months, 12 days * [[Vespasian]] = reign: 9 years, 7 months, 12 days * [[Titus]] = reign: 2 years, 2 months, 2 days * [[Domitian]] = reign: 15 years, 5 months * [[Nerva]] = reign: 1 year, 4 months * [[Trajan]] = reign: 19 years * [[Hadrian]] = reign: 21 years * [[Antoninus Pius|Antoninus, surnamed Pius]] = reign: 22 years * [[Marcus Aurelius|Marcus Aurelius Antoninus]] (otherwise known as Verus, as also known as Commodus Lucius) = reign: 19 years<ref>''Epiphanius' Treatise on Weights and Measures - The Syriac Version'' (ed. James Elmer Dean), University of Chicago Press 1935, p. 35 (top)</ref> Of these years, 7 years he ruled jointly with [[Lucius Aurelius Commodus]] * [[Commodus]] II = reign: 13 years * [[Pertinax]] = reign: 6 months * [[Septimius Severus|Severus]] (reigned jointly with his son, Antoninus) = reign: 18 years * [[Caracalla]], also called Geta, who is also Antoninus = reign: 7 years (ruled jointly with Lucius Aurelius Commodus) * [[Macrinus]] = reign: 1 year * [[Elagabalus|Antoninus II]] = reign: 4 years * [[Severus Alexander|Alexander, the son of Mammaea]] = reign: 13 years * [[Maximinus Thrax|Maximian]] = reign: 3 years * [[Gordian I|Gordian]] = reign: 6 years<ref>Modern chroniclers put Gordian's reign at no more than 21 days. Perhaps Epiphanius simply consolidated the reigns of Gordian I, Gordian II and Gordian III, since they were of the same family.</ref> * [[Philip the Arab|Philip]] = reign: 7 years * [[Decius]] = reign: 1 year, 3 months * [[Trebonianus Gallus|Gallienus (Gallus)]], who ruled jointly with [[Volusianus]] = reign: 2 years, 4 months * [[Valerian (emperor)|Valerian]], who ruled jointly with [[Gallienus]], also known as Gallus = reign: 12 years * [[Claudius Gothicus|Claudius]] = reign: 1 year, 9 months * [[Aurelian]] = reign: 5 years, 6 months * [[Tacitus (emperor)|Tacitus]] = reign: 6 months * [[Marcus Aurelius Probus|Probus]] = reign: 6 years, 4 months * [[Carus]], who ruled jointly with his sons, [[Carinus]] and [[Numerian]] = reign: 2 years * [[Diocletian]], who ruled jointly with [[Galerius|Maximian]], Constantine and Maxentius = reign: 20 years * [[Maximian]], [[Licinius]] and [[Constantine the Great|Constantine]], who ruled in succession one after the other = reign: 32 years<ref>According to [[Gildas Sapiens]]’ ''De Excidio et Conquestu Britanniae'', Maximian, Licinius and Constantine ruled jointly over the Roman Empire, lasting altogether for 32 years.</ref> * [[Constans]], [[Constantine II (emperor)|Constantine]] and [[Constantius II|Constantius]], followed by [[Julian (emperor)|Julian]], [[Jovian (emperor)|Jovian]], [[Valentinian I|Valentinian the Great]], [[Valens]], [[Gratian|Gratian the son of Valentinian]], [[Valentinian II|Valentinian the younger]] (son of [[Valentinian I|Valentinian]]), [[Theodosius I|Theodosius]], [[Arcadius|Arcadius the son of Theodosius]], [[Honorius (emperor)|Honorius the Illustrious]], who was the son of [[Theodosius I|Theodosius]], as far as the time of Epiphanius, during the second consulship of Arcadius Augustus and Rufus = years collected altogether: 57 years
The regnal years of the Caesars as stated by Epiphanius differ slightly in some places from the extant Greek versions. With respect to events in Rome after the reign of [[Pertinax]], both Epiphanius and [[Jerome]] do not mention the ascension of [[Didius Julianus]] after the assassination of Pertinax, but write only that [[Septimius Severus|Severus]] succeeded him.<ref>Cf. ''[[Chronicon (Jerome)|Chronicon]]'' of [[Jerome]], [http://www.tertullian.org/fathers/jerome_chronicle_03_part2.htm 2005 online edition] (tertullian.org), year 193. Epiphanius, by his own admittance (''On Weights and Measures'', p. 66 [folio 71c]), was familiar with [[Eusebius]]' ''Chronicle'' from which Jerome had based his ''Chronicon'' and may have used it to construct his own chronologies.</ref> This may have been because they did not consider his 9-week reign, which he obtained through usurpation, to be legitimate. Similarly, Epiphanius does not mention the ascension of [[Aemilian]]. It can be adduced from Jerome's ''[[Chronicon (Jerome)|Chronicon]]'' that Aemilian, who "caused a revolt in Moesia," was never officially confirmed by the Senate in Rome.<ref>''[[Chronicon (Jerome)|Chronicon]]'' of [[Jerome]], [http://www.tertullian.org/fathers/jerome_chronicle_03_part2.htm 2005 online edition] (tertullian.org), year 254</ref> Epiphanius' method of recording the regnal years from Augustus to Hadrian, with his pinpoint recollection of the number of months and days to each reign, can be said to be accurate, based on [[Josephus]]' own testimony about himself, saying that he was aged 56 in the 13th year of the reign of Caesar [[Domitian]],<ref>Josephus, ''[[Antiquities of the Jews|Antiquities]]'' (20.11.3)</ref> and that he (Josephus) was born in the 1st year of Caesar [[Caligula|Gaius]].<ref>Josephus, ''[[The Life of Flavius Josephus|Vita]]'' § 1</ref> Using Epiphanius' chronology, the years are indeed collected as 56. By comparison, the span of years in [[Suetonius]]' ''De vita Caesarum'' (Lives of the Caesars), which gives 14 years for Claudius and 15 years for Nero, the same time frame would span a period of some 58 years!<ref>Suetonius, ''Lives of the Caesars'' (the Loeb Classical Library series), vol. ii, book v, paragraph xlv</ref>
==See also== * [[List of Roman emperors]] * [[Ptolemaic dynasty]] ==Additional reading== * Renan Baker, "Epiphanius, 'On Weights and Measures' §14: Hadrian's Journey to the East and the Rebuilding of Jerusalem", pub. in: [[Zeitschrift für Papyrologie und Epigraphik]], vol. 182 (2012), pp. 157-167
==References== {{reflist|40em}}
==External links== * [https://oi.uchicago.edu/research/publications/saoc/saoc-11-epiphanius%E2%80%99-treatise-weights-and-measures-syriac-version Epiphanius’ ''Treatise on Weights and Measures: The Syriac Version''], Studies in Ancient Oriental Civilization (SAOC) * [https://oi.uchicago.edu/sites/oi.uchicago.edu/files/uploads/shared/docs/saoc11.pdf PDF format of Epiphanius' ''On Weights and Measures'']
{{Authority control}}

'''Paolo Buzzi''' (15 February 1874, [[Milan]] – 18 February 1956) was an [[Italy|Italian]] [[Futurism (art)|futurist]] [[playwright]] and [[poet]].
==Biography== Buzzi studied [[law]] in [[Pavia]], and at the same time attended [[lecture]]s in [[literature]]. In 1891, he won the [[milanese]] ''Concorso di Poesia'' award. In 1898 with ''Rapsodie leopardiane'' his poetry career begun in ernest. In 1905 he won the title of ''Best Italian Language Poet'' in a competition in the [[literary magazine]] ''Poesia'', founded by [[Marinetti]] and [[Sem Benelli]]. He started thus to write for ''Poesia'', and became a noted futurist, experimenting with poetical and theatrical form. He also tried [[filming]]. In later years he left the futurist work ethos and worked with traditional forms of poetry.
==Works==
*Poesie leopardiane 1898, Galli e Raimondi, [[Milano]] *L'esilio, 1906, Galli e Raimondi, Milano *Aeroplani, 1909, Edizioni di "Poesia", Milano *Versi liberi Treves, 1913, Milano *L'Elisse e la spirale, 1915, Edizioni di "Poesia", Milano *Bel canto", 1916, Studio Editoriale, Lombardo *Popolo, canta così! 1920, Facchi, Milano *Poema dei quarantanni, 1922, Edizioni di "Poesia", Milano *Canti per le chiese vuote, 1930, [[Foligno]] Campitelli *Poema di radioonde, 1940 *Atomiche, 1950
{{Authority control}}

The '''pataphysical calendar''' is a [[calendar]] that is inspired by Alfred Jarry, the creator of the '[[pataphysics]] and the author of [[Ubu Roi]].
The first version of the calendar was published in ''L'Almanach du Père Ubu'' in [[1889]]. The second version was released in [[1901]] in the ''L'Almanach illustré du Père Ubu''. The calendar started to get used in the [[Collège de 'Pataphysique]] in [[1948]], after the death of Jarry.
The calendar has 13 months with each 29 days. The 29th day however, is not used, except for ''29 Gidouille'' (as an exception) and ''29 Gueule'' in a [[leap year]]. The months always start on a Sunday, so that every month has a [[Friday the 13th]]. The names of the days are equal to the general calendar (the French names are mostly used), except for the 29th (the [[Imaginary number|imaginary]] day), which name is ''Hunyadi''. 29 Gueule is called ''Hunyadi gras'' (fat hunyadi).
To make it not that hard for the reader, one places the vulgar (standard) date after the date.
== Months == The year has the following months: {| style="margin-bottom: 10px;" |  1   | Absolu |September 8 until October 5 |- |  2 | Haha |October 6 until November 2 |- |  3 | As | November 3 until November 30 |- |  4 | Sable | December 1 until December 28 |- |  5 | Décervelage  | December 29 until January 25 |- |  6 | Gueules | January 26 until February 22/23 |- |  7 | Pédale | February 23/24 until March 22 |- |  8 | Clinamen | March 23 until April 19 |- |  9 | Palotin | April 20 until May 17 |- | 10 | Merdre | May 18 until June 14 |- | 11 | Gidouille | June 15 until July 13 |- | 12 | Tatane | July 14 until August 10 |- | 13 | Phalle |August 11 until September 7 |} The names are inspired by the exceptional terminology and [[neologisms]] in the work of Jarry. In his play, he wrote ''merd'''r'''e ''instead of ''merde'', which literally means poop - ''o'''n'''eille'' instead of ''oreille'', which means ear.
== Calendar era == The calendar era starts on 1 Absolu 1 EP (= Ère 'Pataphysique), the birth day of Alfred Jarry (September 8, 1873).
== Saints == The calendar has its own saints, like ''the holy [[Joseph-Ignace Guillotin|Guillotine]], medic'' (13 Décervelage = January 10), ''the holy ''[[Hieronymus Bosch]] (17 Clinamen = April 8) and ''the Childbirth of the holy ''[[Pope Joan|Johanna Pausin]] (1 Merdre = May 18)
== External link == * [http://www.college-de-pataphysique.org/wa_files/calenpat.pdf The pataphysical calendar with every saint] {{Fr icon}} [[Category:Calendars]]

revision.text:
[[File:Professor Peter Davies in Tokyo, Japan, October 2011.jpg|thumb|Peter Davies in Tokyo, Japan, October 2011]]
'''Peter N. Davies''' (born 14 July 1927) is a British economic historian with interests in the port of [[Liverpool]], sea-based trade with [[West Africa]], the [[Canary Islands]] and [[Japan]], the international fruit trade and the military history of the [[Khwae Yai River|River Kwai]] campaign in [[World War II]]. He is now an Emeritus Professor in the School of History at the [[University of Liverpool]], [[England]].
Davies is the author of several books including, "The Trade Makers, [[Elder Dempster]] in West Africa" (Allen and Unwin, 1973), "Trading in West Africa" (Croom Helm, 1976), "Sir Alfred Jones: Shipping Entrepreneur par Excellence" (Europa, 1978), "[[Fyffes]] and the Banana, Musa Sapientum" (Athlone Press, 1990), "Japanese Shipping and Shipbuilding Industries: A History of Their Modern Growth" (with T. Chida, Athlone Press, 1990), "The Man Behind the Bridge: Colonel Toosey and the [[Khwae Yai River|River Kwai]]" (Athlone Press, 1991), and "From Orchard to Market" (with D.Hope-Mason, Lockwood Press, 2005).
During a long career at the [[University of Liverpool]], Davies has continued the tradition of commitment to Maritime History which had been initiated by Francis Hyde and maintained by John Harris (subsequently Professor of Economic History at the [[University of Birmingham]]) and Sheila Marriner. Taken together, Hyde, Harris, Marriner and Davies have become known as the "Liverpool School of Maritime Historians".<ref>Davies PN, "The Liverpool School of Maritime History". International Journal of Maritime History (2005);XVII, 2 pp249–260.</ref><ref>Milne G, "Trade and Traders in Mid-Victorian Liverpool: Mercantile Business and the Making of a World Port" (Liverpool University Press, 2000) pp 5–6.</ref>
"The Business, Life and Letters of Frederick Cornes : Aspects of the Evolution of Commerce in Modern Japan, 1861-1912" (Global Oriental: {{ISBN|1-905246-34-X}}) was published in September 2008. In this book Davies examines the surprisingly well-preserved papers of Frederick Cornes, a merchant from [[Cheshire]], England who spent much of his life trading in Japan's port city of [[Yokohama]] during and after the [[Meiji Restoration]], including the entire correspondence of "Cornes and Company" extending over a forty-year period in the early years of Anglo-Japanese trade.
Davies's latest book, "Across the Three Pagodas Pass: The Story of the Thai-Burma Railway" (Renaissance Books: {{ISBN|978-1-898823-07-0}}), was published in August 2013. Davies acted as editor to Ewart Escritt's translation of the personal records of Japanese Railway Engineer Yoshihiko Futamatsu. Davies had come to know Futamatsu through his research for the 1991 biography of [[Philip Toosey]] "The Man Behind the Bridge" and secured his agreement that his memoirs could be published in English after his death.<ref>Davies PN (ed), Futamatsu Y "Across the Three Pagodas Pass: The Story of the Thai-Burma Railway" (Renaissance Books: {{ISBN|978-1-898823-07-0}}).</ref> The book is therefore a rare account from the Japanese viewpoint of the construction of the Thai-Burma Railway (and the [[Khwae Yai River|River Kwai]] Bridge) during [[World War II]].
==References== {{Reflist}}

revision.text:
'''Pherecydes of Leros''' ({{IPAc-en|f|ə|ˈ|r|ɛ|s|ᵻ|ˌ|d|iː|z}}; {{lang-grc-gre|Φερεκύδης ὁ Λέριος}}; {{circa}} 450s BC<ref>G. Huxley, in ''Greek, Roman and Byzantine Studies'' '''14''' (1973:137–43) places his career in the lifetime of [[Cimon]] son of [[Miltiades the Younger]].</ref>) was a [[Greek mythology|Greek mythographer]] and [[logographer (history)|logographer]]. He came from the island of [[Leros]]. Pherecydes spent the greater part of his working life in [[Athens]], and so he was also called '''Pherecydes of Athens''' ({{lang-grc-gre|Φερεκύδης ὁ Ἀθηναῖος}}): the encyclopedic Byzantine ''[[Suda]]'' considers Pherecydes of Athens and of Leros separately.<ref>Suda φ 216, 217</ref>
Pherecydes of Leros should not be confused with [[Pherecydes of Syros]], the mid-6th-century [[philosopher]], who was sometimes mentioned as one of the [[Seven Sages of Greece]] and was reputed to have been the teacher of [[Pythagoras]].
== Works == Pherecydes's great treatises—a history of his native isle, [[Leros]] (Περὶ Λέρου); an essay, ''On [[Iphigeneia]]'' (Περὶ Ἰφιγενείας); and ''On the Festivals of [[Dionysus]]'' (Περὶ τῶν Διονύσου ἑορτῶν)—are all lost. However, numerous fragments of his ten-book [[genealogy|genealogies]] of the [[god]]s and [[hero]]es, which was written in the [[Ionic dialect|Ionian]] dialect to glorify the ancestors in the heroic age of his 5th-century patrons, have been preserved. Pherecydes modified the [[legend]]s, not in order to rationalize them, but rather to adjust them to popular [[belief]]s. Therefore, Pherecydes cannot be classed with the earlier mythographer [[Hecataeus of Miletus]], whose ''Genealogiai'' ("Genealogies") were more skeptical and critical.
Pherecydes was the main source for the mythological encyclopedia, the ''[[Bibliotheca (Pseudo-Apollodorus)|Bibliotheke]]'' mistakenly connected with the name of [[Apollodorus of Athens]].
==Notes== {{reflist}}
{{Authority control}}
{{DEFAULTSORT:Pherecydes of Leros}} [[Category:People from Leros]] [[Category:Early Greek historians]] [[Category:Metics in Classical Athens]] [[Category:5th-century BC historians]] [[Category:Ancient Greek mythographers]] [[Category:5th-century BC Athenians]] [[Category:Year of birth unknown]] [[Category:Year of death unknown]]

revision.text:
'''Sigebert IV''' (c. 671 - c. 679) was the son of [[Dagobert II]] and a Saxon duchess called Mathildis (also called Mechthilde),<ref>According to the 8th century [[Vita Sancti Wilfrithi]] ('' Life of St Wilfrid''), and also mentioned in a version of the ''Vita Sancti Arbogasti''.</ref> and the grandson of [[Sigebert III]] of the [[Merovingian dynasty]].<ref>The early 8th century ''Vita Amandi Episcopi'' referred to "Sygiberto" [http://daten.digitale-sammlungen.de/~db/bsb00000752/images/index.html?id=00000752&fip=213.140.22.76&no=1&seite=450] and to "Sigebertum, Dagoberti Filium" [http://daten.digitale-sammlungen.de/~db/bsb00000752/images/index.html?id=00000752&fip=213.140.22.76&no=12&seite=460]</ref><ref>Historians tend to ignore the importance of these references, [[François Eudes de Mézeray]], in ''Histoire de France'' (Paris, 1685) referred to an anonymous son, and doubted his existence.</ref> He is believed to have died either just before or after his father and other members of the royal family, who were killed on the orders of [[Ebroin]], the [[Franks|Frankish]] [[Mayor of the Palace]] of [[Neustria]].<ref>René Descadeillas, ''Mythologie du Trésor de Rennes: Histoire Veritable de L'Abbé Saunière, Curé de Rennes-le-Château'', Annexe VI (Mémoires de la Société des Arts et des Sciences de Carcassonne, Annees 1971-1972, 4me série, Tome VII, 2me partie; 1974).</ref>
In the 10th-century biography of [[Saint Arbogast]], ''Vita Sancti Argobasti'',<ref>Utho Argentinensis, ''Vita Sancti Arbogasti episcopi argentinensis in Germania prima'' (Apud Bolland., Junii tom. V, p. 170). [http://gallica.bnf.fr/ark:/12148/bpt6k5523567k/f502.image] This version of the text does not refer to Mathildis.</ref> Sigebert is mentioned but not named as having died during a hunting accident and later miraculously raised from the dead by Arbogast, [[Bishop of Strasbourg]] and close friend of Dagobert II.<ref>Christian Settipani, in ''La Prehistoire des Capetiens'' (1993) argued that the ''Vita Sancti Arbogasti'' is too late a source to be accepted without care, and points to evidence that it places Arbogast and his successor Florentius up to a century too late (Arbogast died in around 600). He argues that the trio of Dagobert II, and his alleged wife Mathildis and son Sigebert, may actually have arisen from confusion with Dagobert I, his wife Nanthilde and son Sigebert (his mother was actually Ragnetrude).</ref>
== Priory of Sion == According to the [[Pseudohistory|pseudohistorical]] ''[[Dossiers Secrets d'Henri Lobineau]]'' and related documents, Sigebert IV, on the assassination of his father [[Dagobert II]], was rescued by his sister and smuggled to the domain of his mother the (otherwise unknown) [[Visigoths|Visigoth]] princess, Giselle de Razès in [[Rennes-le-Château]]. He is said to have arrived in the [[Languedoc]] in 681 and, at some point, adopted or inherited his uncle's titles, [[duke]] of [[Razès]] and [[count]] of [[Rhedae]]. He is also said to have adopted the surname, or nickname, of “Plant-Ard” (subsequently Plantard) from the [[French language|French]] appellation ‘''rejeton ardent''’ ‘ardently flowering shoot’ of the Merovingian vine. Under this name, and under the titles acquired from his uncle, he is said to have perpetuated his lineage.<ref name="Baigent, Leigh & Lincoln 1982">{{cite book| author = [[Michael Baigent|Baigent, Michael]]; [[Richard Leigh (author)|Leigh, Richard]]; [[Henry Lincoln|Lincoln, Henry]]| title = [[The Holy Blood and the Holy Grail]] | publisher = Corgi| year = 1982| isbn = 0-552-12138-X}}</ref>
Journalists and scholars who have [[Debunker|debunked]] the [[Priory of Sion]] hoax argue that [[Pierre Plantard]] created the ''Dossiers Secrets d'Henri Lobineau'' and the fictitious biography of Sigebert IV to support his false claim that he was a descendant of the extinct Merovingian dynasty through this figure.<ref>Jean-Luc Chaumeil, ''The Priory of Sion - Shedding Light on the Treasure and Legacy of Rennes-le-Château and the Priory of Sion'' (Avalonia, 2010).</ref> In 1990, Plantard revised himself by claiming he was only descended from a [[cadet branch]] of the line of Dagobert II, while arguing that the direct descendant was really [[Otto von Habsburg]],<ref>Quoting Pierre Plantard: "If anyone can claim to be a descendant of Sigisbert IV in the direct line it can only be Otto von Habsburg, and he alone. To all those people who write to me I have given this same reply." From ''Vaincre – Reprend le titre d'un périodique paru en 1942-1943'', Number 1, April 1990 {{cite web |url=http://jhaldezos.free.fr/lespersonnages/plantard/images/Vaincre%20avril%201990.pdf |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2011-08-18 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110818232934/http://jhaldezos.free.fr/lespersonnages/plantard/images/Vaincre%20avril%201990.pdf |archivedate=2011-08-18 |df= }}</ref> who, according to Plantard, was descended from Sigebert I (the son of Bera II and the grandson of [[Wamba, Visigothic king|Wamba]]), who married Magdala, the granddaughter of Dagobert II.<ref>Quoting Plantard: "We would like to repeat that in no case have we found any trace of the son of Dagobert II in the list of the Visigothic Razes. This Sigibert IV found refuge with his abbess sister at Oeren and was the cousin of Sigebert de Rhedae, who was alive more or less around the same time. Historians conflate these two Sigiberts into one person. When did Sigebert IV die? We don't know. Some think that he was the founder of the Habsburg family."</ref><ref>Jean-Luc Chaumeil, ''Le trésor du Triangle d'Or'', page 163 (Nice: Alain Lefeuvre, 1979).</ref>

[[fr:Faux Mérovingiens#Sigebert IV et Sigebert V]]

[[File:Millcreek chert hoes Nodena site HRoe 01.jpg|thumb|Stone hoes from America. The first basalt hoes in the Near East would have looked similar to these.]] [[File:Wooden hoe.JPG|thumb|Chinese hoes made of wood]] [[File:Hoe 2.jpg|thumb|Modern Hoe]] [[File:Hoe 1.jpg|thumb|Hoe or "Al" is repeated excessively in the song for literary effect]] {{Mesopotamian myth (7)}}
The '''Song of the hoe''' or the '''Creation of the pickax''' is a [[Sumerian creation myth]], written on [[clay tablet]]s from the last century of the [[3rd millennium BCE]].<ref name="Kramer1979">{{cite book|author=Samuel Noah Kramer|title=From the poetry of Sumer: creation, glorification, adoration|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=tZSdbj5Hny0C&pg=PA25|accessdate=10 June 2011|date=April 1979|publisher=University of California Press|isbn=978-0-520-03703-8|pages=25–}}</ref>
==Disputations==
Seven debate topics are known from the Sumerian literature, falling in the category of [[disputation]]s; some examples are: The [[Debate between sheep and grain]]; The [[Debate between bird and fish]]; the [[Debate between Winter and Summer]]; and ''The Dispute between Silver and Copper'', etc.<ref name="Kramer1964">{{cite book|author=Samuel Noah Kramer|title=The Sumerians: their history, culture and character|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=iY9xp4pLp88C&pg=PA220|accessdate=23 May 2011|date=1964|publisher=University of Chicago Press|isbn=978-0-226-45238-8|pages=218–}}</ref> These topics came some centuries after writing was established in Sumerian [[Mesopotamia]]. The debates are [[philosophy|philosophical]] and address humanity's place in the world. Some of the debates may be from 2100 BC.<ref>[http://www.alibris.com/search/books/isbn/9781157463887 Sumerian literature]</ref> The song of the hoe stands alone in its own sub-category as a one-sided debate poem.<ref name="BlackBlack2006">{{cite book|author1=Jeremy A. Black|author2=Jeremy Black|author3=Graham Cunningham|author4=Eleanor Robson|title=The Literature of Ancient Sumer|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=a1W2mTtGVV4C&pg=PA311|accessdate=10 June 2011|date=13 April 2006|publisher=Oxford University Press|isbn=978-0-19-929633-0|pages=311–}}</ref>
==Compilation==
Three tablets of the myth are held by the [[British Museum]], numbers 80170, 132243 (unpublished) and 139993.<ref name="Antiquities">{{cite book|author=British Museum. Dept. of Egyptian and Assyrian Antiquities|title=Cuneiform texts from Babylonian tablets in the British museum, 44, 10|publisher=The Trustees}}</ref><ref name="Antiquities2">{{cite book|author=British Museum. Dept. of Egyptian and Assyrian Antiquities|title=Cuneiform texts from Babylonian tablets in the British museum, 58, 52|publisher=The Trustees}}</ref> Two tablets of the myth are held by the [[Louvre]] in [[Paris]], number AO 7087 & AO 8898.<ref name="antiqueorientales">{{cite book|author1=Musée du Louvre. Département des antiquités orientales et de la céramique antique|author2=Musée du Louvre. Département des antiquités orientales|title=Textes cunéiformes, 16, 72 & 92|publisher=Librairie orientaliste, Paul Geuthner}}</ref> One is held in the [[Vorderasiatisches Museum Berlin]], number 17378 and three at the [[Yale]] Babylonian collection, numbers 5487, 7070 and 11941.<ref name="AbteilungZimmern1966">{{cite book|display-authors=4|author1=Königliche Museen zu Berlin. Vorderasiatische Abteilung|author2=Heinrich Zimmern|author3=Otto Schroeder|author4=H. H. Figulla|author5=Wilhelm Förtsch|author6=Friedrich Delitzsch|title=Vorderasiatische Schriftdenkmäler 24, 68|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=ZA5mYgEACAAJ|accessdate=4 June 2011|publisher=Louis D. Levine}}</ref> Lines of the [[myth]] were discovered on the [[University of Pennsylvania Museum of Archaeology and Anthropology]], catalogue of the [[Babylonia]]n section (CBS), from their excavations at the [[temple]] [[library]] at [[Nippur]]. Tablets from this collection, numbers 8111, 13122, 13382 and 13864 were documented by [[Edward Chiera]] in ''"Sumerian Epics and Myths"''.<ref name="Chiera1964">{{cite book|author=Edward Chiera|title=Sumerian epics and myths, 33, 34, 37 and 39|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=nEFCPgAACAAJ|accessdate=28 May 2011|date=1964|publisher=The University of Chicago Press}}</ref> [[Samuel Noah Kramer]] included CBS tablets 8531, 10310, 10335, 29.16.23, 29.16.436. He also included translations from tablets in the Nippur collection of the [[Istanbul Archaeology Museums|Museum of the Ancient Orient]] in [[Istanbul]], catalogue numbers 1117, 2337, 2473, 2742.<ref name="Kramer1961">{{cite book|author=Samuel Noah Kramer|title=Sumerian mythology: a study of spiritual and literary achievement in the third millennium B.C.|pages=75 & 165|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=t16tDOHZLLEC|accessdate=10 June 2011|date=1961|publisher=Forgotten Books|isbn=978-1-60506-049-1}}</ref><ref name="Kramer1944">{{cite book|author=Samuel Noah Kramer|title=Sumerian literary texts from Nippur: in the Museum of the Ancient Orient at Istanbul|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=hqdIGQAACAAJ|accessdate=28 May 2011|date=1944|publisher=American Schools of Oriental Research}}</ref><ref name="CigKizilyay1969">{{cite book|author1=Muazzez Cig|author2=Hatice Kizilyay|title=Sumerian literary tablets and fragments in the archeological museum of Istanbul-I|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=vrEnGwAACAAJ|accessdate=28 May 2011|date=1969|publisher=Tarih Kurumu Basimevi}}</ref> Other tablets were added from the ''"Ur excavations texts"'' in 1928 along with several others to bring it to its present form, which is virtually complete.<ref name="Mesopotamiamuseum1928">{{cite book|author1=British museum and Pennsylvania University. University museum. Joint expedition to Mesopotamia|author2=Pennsylvania University. University museum|title=Ur excavations texts... 6/3 152, 6/3 168, 6/3 206|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=4GF1QwAACAAJ|accessdate=28 May 2011|date=1928|publisher=British museum}}</ref> The latest composite text and translation was produced in 1996 by H. Behrens, B. Jagersma and Joachim Krecher.<ref>[http://www-etcsl.orient.ox.ac.uk/section5/b554.htm The song of the hoe - Bibliography - The Electronic Text Corpus of Sumerian Literature, Oxford 1998-.] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090403075808/http://www-etcsl.orient.ox.ac.uk/section5/b554.htm |date=2009-04-03 }}</ref>
==Story== The poem is composed of the frequent use of the word "al", which means [[hoe (tool)|hoe]]. The verb-forms and nouns also frequently start with, or contain the syllable "al" (or "ar"), suggesting the writer intended it for humour as a satirical school text or as a [[tongue-twister]].<ref name="HalloYounger1997">{{cite book|author1=William W. Hallo|author2=K. Lawson Younger|title=The Context of Scripture: Canonical compositions from the biblical world|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=es6BaGkU4XIC|accessdate=10 June 2011|date=January 1997|publisher=Brill|isbn=978-90-04-10618-5}}</ref> The song starts with a creation myth where [[Enlil]] separates heaven and earth in [[Duranki]], the cosmic [[Nippur]] or '[[Garden of the gods (Sumerian paradise)|Garden of the Gods]]'.
{{cquote|''"Not only did the lord make the world appear in its correct form, the lord who never changes the destinies which he determines – Enlil – who will make the human seed of the Land come forth from the earth – and not only did he hasten to separate heaven from earth, and hasten to separate earth from heaven, but, in order to make it possible for humans to grow in "where flesh came forth" [the name of a cosmic location], he first raised the axis of the world at [[Dur-an-ki]].<ref name="ETCSL">[http://www-etcsl.orient.ox.ac.uk/section5/tr554.htm ETCSL Translation] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090402070726/http://www-etcsl.orient.ox.ac.uk/section5/tr554.htm |date=2009-04-02 }}</ref>}}
The myth continues with a description of Enlil creating daylight with his hoe; he goes on to praise its construction and creation. Enlil's mighty hoe is said to be made of [[gold]], with the blade made of [[lapis lazuli]] and fastened by cord. It is inlaid with lapis lazuli and adorned with [[silver]] and gold. Enlil makes civilized man, from a [[brick]] mould with his hoe – and the [[Annanuki]] start to praise him. [[Nisaba]], [[Ninmena]], and [[Nunamnir]] start organizing things. [[Enki]] praises the hoe; they start reproducing and Enlil makes numerous shining hoes, for everyone to begin work. Enlil then founds the [[Ekur]] with his hoe whilst a "god-man" called Lord [[Nudimmud]] builds the [[Abzu]] in [[Eridug]]. Various gods are then described establishing construction projects in other cities, such as [[Ninhursag]] in [[Kesh (Sumer)|Kesh]], and [[Inanna]] and [[Utu]] in [[Zabalam]]; [[Nisaba]] and [[E-ana]] also set about building.<ref name="ETCSL"/> The useful construction and agricultural uses of the hoe are summarized, along with its capabilities for use as a [[weapon]] and for burying the dead. Allusions are made to the scenes of [[Enkidu]]'s [[ghost]], and [[Urshanabi]]'s ferry over the [[Hubur]], in the [[Epic of Gilgamesh]]:
{{cquote|''"dead people are also brought up from the ground by the hoe. With the hoe, the hero honoured by [[Anu|An]], the younger brother of [[Nergal]], the warrior [[Gilgamesh]] – is as powerful as a hunting net. The sage son of [[Ninsumun]] is pre-eminent with [[oar]]s. With the hoe, he is the great "kindajal" of the [[watercourse]]s.<ref name="ETCSL"/>}}
[[Ninmena]] is suggested to create both the [[priest]]ess and [[king]].<ref name="religious of the past">{{cite book|title=religious of the past|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=0sgUAAAAIAAJ&pg=PA140|accessdate=10 June 2011|publisher=Brill Archive|pages=140–|id=GGKEY:SDQ069KTBZ0}}</ref> The hymn ends with extensive praisings of the hoe, Enlil, and Nisaba:
{{cquote|''"The hoe makes everything prosper; the hoe makes everything flourish. The hoe is good [[barley]]; the hoe is an overseer. The hoe is brick moulds; the hoe has made people exist. It is the hoe that is the strength of young manhood. The hoe and the [[basket]] are the tools for building [[cities]]. It builds the right kind of house; it cultivates the right kind of fields. It is you, hoe, that extend the good agricultural land!<ref name="ETCSL"/>}}
==Discussion==
Modern society may have trouble comprehending the virtue of extolling a tool such as the lowly hoe, for the Sumerians the implement had brought [[agriculture]], [[irrigation]], [[drainage]] and the ability to build roads, canals and eventually the first proto-cities.<ref name="Kramer1979"/> One of the tablets from the Yale Babylonian Collection was published by J.J. Van Dijk which spoke of three cosmic realms; heaven, earth and [[kur]] in a time when darkness covered an arid land, when heaven and earth were joined and the Enlil's universal laws, the [[Me (mythology)|me]] did not function.<ref name="Kramer1979"/> Two of the major traditions of the Sumerian concept of the creation of man are discussed in the myth. The first is the creation of mankind from brick moulds or clay. This has notable similarities to the creation of man from the dust of the earth in the [[Book of Genesis]] in the [[Bible]] ({{Bibleverse|Genesis|2:6-7|HE}}). This activity has also been associated with creating clay figurines.<ref name="Frymer-Kensky2006">{{cite book|author=Tikva Simone Frymer-Kensky|author-link=Tikva Frymer-Kensky|title=Studies in Bible and feminist criticism|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=cDEtHfEpp7sC&pg=PA21|accessdate=10 June 2011|date=May 2006|publisher=Jewish Publication Society|isbn=978-0-8276-0798-9|pages=21–}}</ref> The second Sumerian tradition which compares men to plants, made to "break through the ground", an allusion to imagery of the fertility or mother goddess and giving an image of man being "planted" in the ground.<ref name="Frymer-Kensky2006"/> Wayne Horowitz notes that five Sumerian myths recount a creation scene with the separation of heaven and earth. He further notes the figurative imagery relaying the relationship between the creation of agricultural implements making a function for mankind and thereby its creation from the "seed of the land".<ref name="Horowitz1998">{{cite book|author=Wayne Horowitz|title=Mesopotamian cosmic geography|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=P8fl8BXpR0MC&pg=PA134|accessdate=10 June 2011|date=1998|publisher=Eisenbrauns|isbn=978-0-931464-99-7|pages=134–}}</ref> The myth was called the "Creation of the Pickax" by Samuel Noah Kramer, a name by which it is referred in older sorurces. In Sumerian literature, the hoe or pickaxe is used not only in creation of the Ekur but also described as the tool of its destruction in lament hymns such as the [[Lament for Ur]], where it is torn apart with a storm and then pickaxes.<ref name="Dobbs-Allsopp1993">{{cite book|author=F. W. Dobbs-Allsopp|title=Weep, O daughter of Zion: a study of the city-lament genre in the Hebrew Bible|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=_4m-5MqIGYsC&pg=PA57|accessdate=10 June 2011|date=1993|publisher=GBPress Pont. Ist.Biblicum|isbn=978-88-7653-346-4|pages=57–}}</ref>
The cosmological position of the hoe does not fit into [[Charles H. Long|Charles Long]]'s categorization of cosmogenic myths. Creation has been suggested to have been the responsibility of different gods via different processes. Creation via a cosmological agricultural implement seems to occupy a unique place in the creation myth genre. The song was meant to be sung aloud with the repetition of the word hoe or "al" a total of forty five times in the text with common use of the two [[syllable]]s together "al"/"ar". A cosmological link is suggested between the hoe's ''being'' and its ''doing''; making everything prosper and flourish within a [[community]]. Gary Martin discusses the sociological benefits of singing songs to a hoe, to remind people that they wield the implement of Enlil and of creation. That they can participate in creativity and work well to preserve and improve [[society]]. He suggests that "perhaps by praising the simple tool of an extremely important group of laborers, and imbuing it with cosmological significance, those wielders of the hoe are themselves brought into a grand cosmological drama."<ref>http://faculty.washington.edu/garmar/CosmologicalHoeSumer.pdf Martin, Gary., The Cosmological Hoe, University of Washington, 2005.</ref>
==Further reading==
* Civil, Miguel., "Review of CT 44", Journal of Near Eastern Studies 28, 70-72: 70, 1969. * Civil, Miguel., The Farmer's Instructions. A Sumerian Agricultural Manual. (Aula Orientalis Supplementa, 5) Editorial Ausa: Sabadell, 1994. * Edzard, Dietz Otto., "U 7804 // UET VI/1 26: "Gedicht von der Hacke"", in George, A. R. (ed.), and Finkel, I. L., Wisdom, Gods and Literature: Studies in Assyriology in Honour of W. G. Lambert, Eisenbrauns: Winona Lake, 131-135, 2000. * Farber, Gertrud., ""Das Lied von der Hacke", ein literarischer Spass?", in Klengel, Horst and, Renger, Johannes (eds.), Landwirtschaft im Alten Orient: ausgewählte Vorträge der XLI. Rencontre Assyriologique Internationale Berlin., 4.-8.7.1994 (Berliner Beiträge zum Vorderen Orient, 18), Dietrich Reimer Verlag: Berlin, 369-373, 1999. * Farber, Gertrud., "Sumerian Canonical Compositions. A. Divine Focus. 1. Myths: The Song of the Hoe (1.157)", in Hallo, William W. (ed.), The Context of Scripture, I: Canonical Compositions from the Biblical World. Brill: Leiden/New York/Köln, 511-513, 1997. * Jacobsen, Thorkild., "Sumerian Mythology, a Review Article", Journal of Near Eastern Studies 5, 128-152: 134, 1946. * Kramer, Samuel Noah., Sumerian Mythology. The American Philosophical Society: Philadelphia, 51-53, 1944. * Pettinato, Giovanni., Das altorientalische Menschenbild und die sumerischen und akkadischen Schöpfungsmythen. Winter: Heidelberg, 82-85, 1971. * Wilcke, Claus., "Hacke - B. Philologisch", in Reallexikon der Assyriologie 4, 33-38: 36-38, 1972.

{{other uses}} [[File:Nicopolis synoecism.svg|thumb|250px|"Communities participating in the synoecism of Nikopolis and the boundaries of the territory."]] '''Synoecism''' or '''synecism''' ({{IPAc-en|s|ᵻ|ˈ|n|iː|s|ɪ|z|əm}} {{respell|si|NEE|siz-əm}}; {{lang-grc|συνοικισμóς}}, ''sunoikismos'', {{IPA-el|syːnɔi̯kismós|anc}}), also spelled '''synoikism''' ({{IPAc-en|s|ᵻ|ˈ|n|ɔɪ|k|ɪ|z|əm}} {{respell|si|NOY|kiz-əm}}), was originally the amalgamation of villages in [[Ancient Greece]] into ''poleis'', or city-states. Etymologically the word means "dwelling together (''syn'') in the same house (''oikos'')." Subsequently, any act of civic union between polities of any size was described by the word ''synoikismos''. The closest analogy today is the incorporation of a city; in fact, "incorporation" is often used to translate synoikismos, in addition to the Latinized synoecism. Synoecism is opposed to Greek dioecism (διοικισμóς, ''dioikismos''), the creation of independent communities within the territory of a polis.
Synoecism is the result of a few major factors, mainly an increase in population density of adjacent settlements, with an incorporation proposed for economic, political or ideological advantages, such as the synoecism of the communities of [[Attica]] into [[Athens]], or by imposition of a ruling power, such as the synoecism of [[Messenia]] into the newly built city of [[Messene]].
A dioecism is essentially the inverse of a synoecism, the releasing of cities, towns or villages from their association with a polis. This process might manifest itself in several ways, such as the settling of new but independent communities within former territory of [[Constantinople]] on land abandoned due to a contraction of population, or the contraction of [[Thessaloniki]] out of its former neighborhoods outside the city walls due to the occupation of the countryside by the Turks.<ref name="dop57">{{citation|url=http://www.doaks.org/DOP57/DP57ch03.pdf |title=Dumbarton Oaks, Papers, No. 57: Symposium on Late Byzantine Thessaloniki |type=extract |first=Charalambos |last=Bakirtyis |contribution=The Urban Continuity and Size of Late Byzantine Thessalonike |editor-first=Alice-Mary |editor-last=Talbot |year=2004 |origyear=2003 |location=Washington, DC |publisher=Trustees for Harvard University, Dumbarton Oaks Research Library and Collection |pages=40–41, 64 |accessdate=2007-04-03 |format=[[PDF]] |deadurl=unfit |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070221202637/http://www.doaks.org/DOP57/DP57ch03.pdf |archivedate=February 21, 2007 }}</ref> A conqueror might break up a polis for various reasons. As part of the settlement of the [[Third Sacred War]] in 346 BC, the [[Amphictyonic League]] was commissioned to destroy 21 or 22 cities of [[Phocis (ancient region)|Phocis]], many of which had already been burned. They chose the method of dioecism, returning the ''poleis'' to their constituent ''kōmai'', or villages. The city fortifications were then dismantled. This relatively mild destruction was reversed by Athens and Thebes several years later. They were sympathetic to Phocis but their hands had been legally tied. The cities were re-synoecized. The larger states assisted Phocis to rebuild the fortifications.<ref>{{citation | title=An inventory of archaic and classical poleis | editor1-first= Mogens Herman | editor1-last= Hansen | editor2-first= Thomas Heine | editor2-last=Nielsen | contribution= Phokis | first = Jacques | last=Oulhen | year=2004 | location= Oxford | publisher= Oxford University Press | pages = 400–1}}</ref>
==General concept==
Although there were differences between synoecism in [[ancient Greece]] and [[ancient Rome]], the same general concept is deduced from the history of both civilizations. Before political union, the future (combined) population of the polity constituted smaller settlements that were not obligated to each other, or at least not by the contract that was later to institute their political union. A settlement or group of settlements might be constituents of another polity from which they would be annexed or transferred.
==In ancient Greece== In [[ancient Greece]], society was divided into the ''[[deme|demos]]'' (δῆμοι, κῶμαι; "country people" or "country villages") and the "asty" (ἄστυ) or "[[polis]]" (πόλις). The polis was the situs of the princely [[nobility]], gentry, and aristocracy and the sacerdotal and martial families. The distinction between the "demos" and the "polis" was politically very important in these ancient states. There was much antagonism between the two bodies of the country and city. Where commerce and trade came to dominate culture and ideology, they encouraged men to live together in larger towns and develop democracies. In the city states of classical Greece, synoecism occurred when the "demos" combined with and subordinated, usually by force, the "politiea" in one polity.<ref name="rahe">{{cite book |last=Rahe|first=Paul A |title= Republics Ancient and Modern|year=1994|series=I|publisher=University of North Carolina Press|location= Chapel Hill and London |chapter=20 | page = 323}}</ref>
In the ''poleis'', the ''synoikistes'' was the person who according to tradition executed the synoecism, either by charisma or outright conquest; he was subsequently worshiped as a demi-god. The most famous ''synoikistes'' was the mythic and legendary [[Theseus]], who liberated [[Attica, Greece|Attica]] from [[Knossos|Cretan]] hegemony and restored the independence of [[Greece]] under the leadership of [[Athens]].
===In Greek democracies=== In ancient [[Athens]], the villages of [[Attica]] combined with the polis of Athens; consequently the "demos" and "polis" became identical in Athens and the former word assumed preference to denote the whole polity. Popular government was first established in the wealthy and populous Greek cities in [[Ionia]].<ref name ="muller1">{{cite book | last1 = Müller | first1 = Karl Otfried | author1-link = Karl Otfried Müller| first2 = Henry | last2 = Tufnell | author2-link = Henry Tufnell | first3 = George Cornewall | last3 = Lewis | author3-link = George Cornewall Lewis | title = The History and Antiquities of the Doric Race | edition = 2nd | series = 2 | year = 1839 | publisher = John Murray | pages = 72, 72–3}}</ref> From this history the word and concept of "democracy" is derived. This synoecism was one of the primary causes of [[the Kyklos]] in ancient [[Ancient Greece|Hellas]].
Synoecism also occurred in the history of [[Mantineia]]. In the fifth century, after its synoecism, it became a democracy; in the fourth century, it was again divided ("''dioikismos''") and an [[oligarchy]] formed. Later, more political upheaval caused another synoecism, thus instituting another democracy.<ref name="rahe" /> This further occurred in the other [[Arcadia|Arcadian]] towns of [[Tegea]] and [[Heraia, Arcadia|Heraia]].
===In Greek oligarchies=== Ancient Greek states not democratically governed used the word "polis" in their public documents to signify sovereign power. The [[Dorians|Doric]] states of [[Crete]] and [[Sparta]] preserved the polis separate from the demos. As late as the second century AD, Cretan towns continued to denote themselves with "polis". [[Sparta]], however, deviating from this use of the word, denominated itself "damos" (δᾶμoς) in ancient laws, because it never thought of itself as a body opposed to the Perioeci.<ref name="muller1" />
[[Karl Otfried Müller|Müller]] states: "In [[Oligarchy|oligarchical]] states, as in Elis, the people in later times remained almost constantly in the country; and it frequently happened that grandfathers and grandchildren had never seen the town: there were also country courts of justice, and other regulations intended to make up for the advantages of a city life. Where the courts of justice were at a distance, and there was no inducement to mechanical industry and internal commerce (see the term [[banausos]]), the ancient habits of life continued much longer in existence."<ref name="muller1" />
== In ancient Rome == In [[ancient Rome]], some of the kinds of settlement that were incorporated by synoecism into greater municipal polities were the prefecture (''praefectura''), a non-autonomous village administered by a prefect; the ''oppidum'', a fortified, autonomous town; the ''castellum'', a small fortified place under or previously under martial jurisdiction; the ''forum'', being a marketplace; the ''conciliabulum'', being a meeting place; the ''vicus'', being a small, private settlement without government; the ''[[canabae]]'', being a settlement of dependents in the vicinity of a base; the ''[[pagus]]'', being a rural village; the ''gens'', being a tribal canton; the ''saltus'', being a settlement of ''coloni'' (farmers) on a large estate, part of which they leased from the ''conductor'' (manager); and the ''[[Colonia (Roman)|colonia]]'', being a settlement of colonists from [[Rome]].{{Sfn | Abbott |Johnson|1926|pp= 10-20}}
== As an archaeological site == "Synoecism" also denominates an ancient [[Minoan civilization|Cretan]] archaeological site on the western fringes of [[Troullos]]. Artifacts discovered at the site include a [[terracotta]] bull figurine, a bronze statuette, and [[Minoan pottery|Late Minoan I pottery]]. <!--conurbation-->

'''Timothy Charles William Blanning''', [[Fellow of the British Academy|FBA]] (born 21 April 1942) is a historian and retired academic. Between 1992 and 2009, he was Professor of Modern European History at the [[University of Cambridge]].
== Career == Timothy Charles William Blanning was born on 21 April 1942. After attending the [[King's School, Bruton|King's School]] in [[Bruton]], he went up to [[Sidney Sussex College, Cambridge]], graduating with a [[Bachelor of Arts]] degree and then continuing to complete his [[doctorate]] there; his [[Doctor of Philosophy|PhD]] was awarded in 1967. In 1965, he was elected to a research fellowship at Sidney Sussex, and in 1968 was elected to a fellowship there. In the meantime, he was appointed to an assistant lectureship at the [[University of Cambridge]] in 1972, being promoted to lecturer four years later. He was promoted again to be Reader in Modern European History in 1987, and was appointed Professor of Modern European History in 1992. He retired in 2009, but remains at Cambridge as an [[emeritus]] professor.<ref name=":0">[http://www.ukwhoswho.com/abstract/10.1093/ww/9780199540884.001.0001/ww-9780199540884-e-7829 "Blanning, Prof. Timothy Charles William"], ''Who's Who'' (online edition, Oxford University Press, December 2017). Retrieved 17 July 2018.</ref>
=== Research === Blanning's first book, ''Reform and Revolution in [[Electorate of Mainz|Mainz]], 1743–1803'' (1974), offered a case study which could examine the [[German Problem]], the idea that modern Germany began moving apart from Western Europe in political and cultural terms; Blanning sought to demonstrate that this process began in the eighteenth century, whereas earlier historians had emphasised the nineteenth century as a more important period.<ref>[http://admin.cambridge.org/sb/academic/subjects/history/british-history-general-interest/reform-and-revolution-mainz-17431803 "Reform and Revolution in Mainz, 1743–1803 "], ''Cambridge University Press''. Retrieved 17 July 2018.</ref> His second book, ''The French Revolution in Germany: Occupation and Resistance in the Rhineland, 1792–1802'', was published in 1983, and the French Revolution was also the subject of Blanning's ''The Origins of the French Revolutionary Wars'' (1986), ''The French Revolution: Aristocrats versus Bourgeois?'' (1987; a second edition was published in 1998 as ''The French Revolution: Class War or Culture Clash?'') and ''The French Revolutionary Wars'' (1996). In the meantime, he turned to the Habsburg monarchy and produced a biography of the [[Holy Roman Emperor]] [[Joseph II, Holy Roman Emperor|Joseph II]] in 1994; he has also published biographies of [[George I of Great Britain|George I]] (2017) and [[Frederick the Great]] of [[Prussia]] (2015),<ref name=":0" /> the latter of which won the [[British Academy Medal]] in 2016.<ref name=":1" />
Since the early 2000s, Blanning's work has also focused on cultural histories of Europe, beginning in 2002 with his book ''The Culture of Power and the Power of Culture''; this was followed by ''[[The Pursuit of Glory|The Pursuit of Glory: Europe 1648–1815]]'' (2006), ''The Triumph of Music: Composers, Musicians and Audiences, 1700 to the Present'' (2008) and ''The Romantic Revolution'' (2011).<ref name=":0" />
==Honours== In 1990, Blanning was elected a [[Fellow of the British Academy]] (FBA).<ref name="FBA">{{cite web|title=Professor Timothy Blanning|url=http://www.britac.ac.uk/users/professor-timothy-blanning|website=British Academy|accessdate=30 July 2017}}</ref> In September 2016, he was awarded the [[British Academy Medal]] for his book ''[[Frederick the Great: King of Prussia]]'' (2015).<ref name=":1">{{cite web|title=British Academy announces 2016 prizes and medal winners|url=http://www.britac.ac.uk/news/british-academy-announces-2016-prize-and-medal-winners|website=British Academy|accessdate=30 July 2017|date=27 September 2016}}</ref> Blanning was awarded a [[Doctor of Letters]] degree by the University of Cambridge in 1998.<ref name=":0" />
==Works== ===Books authored===
*''Joseph II and Enlightened Despotism'' (Longman, 1970) *''Reform and Revolution in Mainz, 1743–1803'' (Cambridge University Press, 1974) *''The French Revolution in Germany: Occupation and Resistance in the Rhineland, 1792-1802'' (Oxford University Press, 1983) * ''The Origins of the French Revolutionary Wars'' (Longman, 1986) * ''The French Revolution: Aristocrats versus Bourgeois?'' (Macmillan, 1987) *''Joseph II'' (Longman, 1994) *''The French Revolutionary Wars 1787-1802'' (Edward Arnold, 1996) *''The French Revolution: Class War or Culture Clash?'' (Macmillan, 1997) *''The Culture of Power and the Power of Culture: Old Regime Europe, 1660-1789'' (Oxford University Press, 2002) *''[[The Pursuit of Glory: Europe 1648–1815]]'' (Penguin, 2007) *''The Triumph of Music: The Rise of Composers, Musicians and Their Art'' (2008) *''The Romantic Revolution: A History'' (2011) *''Frederick the Great: King of Prussia'' (Allen Lane, 2015) *''George I: The Lucky King'' (Allen Lane, 2017)
===Books edited===
*''The Oxford Illustrated History of Modern Europe'' (Oxford University Press, 1996) *''The Rise and Fall of the French Revolution'' (Chicago University Press, 1996) *with [[David Cannadine]] (eds.), ''History and Biography: Essays in Honour of Derek Beales'' (Cambridge, 1996) *with [[Peter Wende]] (eds.), ''Reform in Great Britain and Germany, 1750-1850'' (Oxford, 1999) *''The Short Oxford History of Europe, vol. 8: The Eighteenth Century'' and ''vol. 9: The Nineteenth Century'' (Oxford University Press, 2000) *''The Oxford History of Modern Europe'' (Oxford University Press, 2000) *with [[Hagen Schulze]] (eds.), ''Unity and Diversity in European Culture c. 1800'' (Oxford, 2006)
